newsitem.title: USA: Mass. issues consumer protection rules for guns.
newsitem.headline: Mass. issues consumer protection rules for guns.

text.p: Massachusetts became the first state in the nation to issue consumer protection regulations for handguns Wednesday that effectively ban the sale of Saturday night specials in the state.

"For the first time anywhere, handguns will face the same common sense consumer safety standards as baby rattles, bicycles and teddy bears," Massachusetts Attorney General Scott Harshbarger told reporters.

The regulations, which will be phased in beginning Oct, and be in full effect by June 1, 1998, "will require all handguns sold in our state to include child-proofing features, tamper-proof serial numbers and detailed consumer safety warnings," Harshbarger said.

The regulations require all handguns sold within the state to meet a minimum quality standing by passing tests for a specific standard for melting point, tensile strength and metal density, and a drop test measuring the potential for accidental discharge.
Those weapons that fail the performance tests will then be required to pass a performance test regarding malfunctions and part wear per rounds fired.

Officials estimated some 30 guns, most of them .22- or .25-caliber weapons, would likely be barred from sale in Massachusetts because "they are junk. They are too cheap and too dangerous," said Eugene Passara, head of the Massachusetts Association of Chiefs of Police firearms committee. None of these is made in the state.

Makers of Saturday night specials, the cheap pistols usually used for impulsive crimes, are primarily made by five gunmakers in southern California: Lorcin, Jennings, Byrco Arms, Phoenix Arms and David Industries.

Firearms are the second leading cause of injury-related death to children and adolsecents in Massachusetts. Nationally, firearms are the fourth leading cause of accidental death in children aged five to 14 years old.
Harshbarger said he was prepared to defend the regulations, which need no legislative approval, in court.
Beginning Oct 1, handguns will come with a detailed written consumer safety warning under the regulations.
"I think everyone agrees that if there's any product that should come with consumer safety warnings, it's a handgun," he said.
